oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Woodlawn Baptist Church: view of front from the cemetery
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color photograph of the front (west) facade of the church, showing the crennelated tower to each side of the entrance. The church has a cross-gable design, with wings extending from each side at the back of the building. Wide green steps lead to double glass entry doors. Two double rectangular windows are to either side of the entrance and four more line the balcony level. Agricultural fields extend behind the church.

Woodlawn Baptist Church was formed at least as early as the 1850s by Harden Smith. From the building of the sanctuary in 1865, to 1890, the congregation grew rapidly. In 1891, an additional 2.5 acres were purchased from James D. and Lucy E. Read to accommodate the expanded congregation. In 1927-28, a new building was constructed. In the 1950s, Rev. J.A. Caldwell launched a campaign to pay off the mortgage and building campaign for a Sunday School annex. The church is known as a community center for Civil Rights activism and as having a long tradition with music.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American Churches -- Tennessee
Churches
